'''Further reading''' * Mackrell, Judith (2013) ''Flappers: Six Women of a Dangerous Generation''. {{ISBN|978-0-330-52952-5}} == External links == {{Commons category|Flappers}} * {{Citation | url = http://www.1920s-fashion-and-music.com/1920s-Flapper.html | contribution = 1920s Flapper: Young Women in a Modern World | title = 1920s fashion & music}}. * {{Citation | url = http://local.aaca.org/bntc/slang/slang.htm | title = Slang of the 1920s | publisher = AACA | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100618074534/http://local.aaca.org/bntc/slang/slang.htm | archivedate = June 18, 2010 | df = mdy-all }}. * {{Citation | url = http://www.rambova.com/fashion/fash4.html | contribution = Flappers and fashion | title = Rambova}} * {{Citation | url = https://www.facebook.com/LouiseBrooksFanClub | title = Thousands of photos of flappers can be viewed at Louise Brooks Fan Club on Facebook}}. {{1920s media culture|state=collapsed}} [[Category:1920s fads and trends|Slang]] [[Category:1920s fashion]] [[Category:Fashion aesthetics]] [[Category:Gender equality]] [[Category:1920s slang]] [[Category:Slang terms for women]] [[Category:Stereotypes of women]]

{{Short description|American performance artist}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = pink | name = Frank Moore | image = Frank Moore - Chicago Art Institute.jpg | caption = Frank Moore in front of the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] 1991 photograph by Linda Mac | birth_name = Frank James Moore | birth_date = June 25, 1946 | birth_place = [[Columbus, Ohio]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|10|14|1946|6|25}} | death_place = [[Berkeley, California]], [[United States]] | nationality = American | field = Performance artist | training = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = }} '''Frank James Moore''' (June 25, 1946 – October 14, 2013) was an American [[performance artist]],<ref name="Carr, C 2008">{{cite news |last = Carr |first=C. |title=''On Edge: Performance at the End of the Twentieth Century'' |publisher=Wesleyan, 2008. pgs. XXI, 138-140 {{ISBN|978-0819568885}}}}</ref> [[shaman]], [[poet]],<ref>{{cite news |editor-last1=Williams |editor-first1=Michael B. |editor-last2=Krezman |editor-first2=Carole Jane |title=Beneath The Surface, Creative Expressions of Augmented Communicators, ISAAC Series, Volume 2 |publisher=PointOne Graphics Inc., 2000. {{ISBN|978-0968418611}}}}</ref> [[essayist]],<ref name="South East Magazine 1989">{{cite news |title=Art Papers Contemporary Art in the South East Magazine, Vol. 13, #6, New York City, June 1989.}}</ref> [[Painting|painter]], [[musician]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Armstrong |first=RD |title=''On/Off The Beaten Path: The Road Poems'' |publisher=(see 'A Journey Up the Coast'). Lummox Press, 1999. {{ISBN|978-1929878994}}}}</ref> and [[Internet]]/television personality who experimented in art,<ref>{{cite news |last=Walker |first=Pamela Kay |title=''Moving Over the Edge: Artists with Disabilities Take the Leap'' |publisher=Davis, California: Michael Horton Media, 2005. pp. 54–69 {{ISBN|0-9771505-2-6}}}}</ref> performance,<ref>{{cite news |last=Carr |first=C. |title=''On Edge: Performance at the End of the Twentieth Century'' |publisher=Wesleyan, 2008. pgs. XXI, 138-140 {{ISBN|978-0819568885}}}}</ref> ritual,<ref>{{cite news |last=Knox |first=Kelly W. |title=IMAGINATION: The Art of Transformation |url=http://techbiotic.com/kwknoxartblog/?p=89 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830143038/http://techbiotic.com/kwknoxartblog/?p=89 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-08-30 }}</ref> and shamanistic teaching since the late 1960s.
Moore was one of the [[National Endowment for the Arts|NEA]]-funded artists targeted by [[Jesse Helms]] and the [[GAO]] (General Accounting Office) in the early 1990s for creating art that was labeled "obscene".<ref>{{cite news |last=Dubin |first=S. |title=Arresting Images: Impolitic Art and Uncivil Actions |publisher=Routledge, 1994. pg.149 {{ISBN|978-0415908931}}}}</ref> He was featured in the 1988 cult film ''[[Mondo New York]]'', which chronicled the leading performance artists of that period.
==Life and career== Moore was born with [[cerebral palsy]], could not walk or talk, and communicated using a laser-pointer and a board of letters, numbers, and commonly used words. Using his pointer, he wrote books, directed plays, directed, acted in and edited films, and regularly gave poetry readings. Moore played piano, sang in ensemble music jams, and led bands in hard core [[Punk rock|punk]] clubs all along the [[West Coast of the United States]] until his death. He also produced, and exhibited across the United States and Canada, a large collection of original oil and digital paintings.
Moore was known for his long (5–48 hours) ritualistic performances with audience participation, nudity, and eroticism.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dubin |first=S. |title=Arresting Images: Impolitic Art and Uncivil Actions |publisher=Routledge, 1994. pg.155 {{ISBN|978-0415908931}}}}</ref> His writings on performance,<ref name="South East Magazine 1989"/> art,<ref>{{cite book |editor-last1=Kaplan |editor-first1=Rachel |editor-last2=Hennessy |editor-first2=Keith |title=More Out Than In: Notes on sex, art & community |publisher=Abundant Fuck Publications |date=1995 |isbn=978-1881430513}}</ref> life,<ref>Moore, Frank. ''Cherotic Magic Revised'', Inter-Relations, 2015. {{ISBN| 978-1515240181}} and Moore, Frank. ''Art Of Living'' from ''Frankly Speaking; A Collection of Essays, Writings and Rants'', Inter-Relations, 2014. Pgs.22-24 {{ISBN| 978-1495443381}} – see also a review of ''Cherotic Magic'': {{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Barbara|title=''Cherotic Magic'' by Frank Moore|url=http://www.eroplay.com/cheroticmagic/cherotic-magic-by-frank-moore-review-by-barbara-smith.html|website=eroplay.com|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> and cultural subversion,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Frank|title=Cultural Subversion|url=http://www.eroplay.com/cultsub.html|website=eroplay.com|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> and his performance/video archive on Vimeo.com seen by over 22 million people, further influence Moore's legacy.
Moore coined the word "eroplay" to describe physical play between adults released from the linear goals of sex and orgasm.<ref>{{cite news |last=Brown |first=Steven |title=''Movie Stars and Sensuous Scars: Essays on the Journey from Disability Shame to Disability Pride'' |publisher=iUniverse, Inc., 2003. pgs. 130-133 {{ISBN|978-0595288939}} }}</ref> He explored this and similar concepts in performance and ritual as a way for people to connect on a deeper level beyond the social and cultural expectations and limitations.<ref>{{cite news |last=Burch |first=S. |title=''Encyclopedia of American Disability History'' |publisher=Facts on File, 2009. {{ISBN|978-0816070305}}}}</ref>
Frank Moore first came to be known in the 1970s as the creator of the popular [[cabaret]] show, the "Outrageous Beauty Revue". In the 1980s Moore attended the [[San Francisco Art Institute]] where he earned his M.F.A. in Performance/Video in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frank Moore's Resume|url=http://www.eroplay.com/Cave/resume.html|website=Eroplay.com|accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref> At this school Moore discovered that the work that he had been doing for over a decade was called performance art.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Frank|title=Sol Divus (aka Michael Peppe) - Frank Moore's Shaman's Den|url=https://vimeo.com/197309142|website=Vimeo|accessdate=7 July 2017}} (2:24:20-2:24:50)</ref> In 1992 he was voted Best Performance Artist by the ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]''. In the early 1990s Moore was targeted by Senator [[Jesse Helms]].<ref name="Carr, C 2008"/><ref>{{cite news |last=Carr |first=C. |title=The Fiery Furnace: Performance in the '80s, War in the '90s |publisher=''TDR: The Drama Review'', Volume 49, Number 1 (T 185), Spring 2005. Pgs. 19-28}}</ref> From 1991 to 1999 Moore published and edited the underground zine ''The Cherotic (r)Evolutionary''.<ref name="Sant 2011. pg. 105">{{cite news |last=Sant |first=Toni |title=''Franklin Furnace and the Spirit of the Avant-Garde: A History of the Future'' |publisher=Intellect Ltd, 2011. pg. 105 {{ISBN|978-1841503714}}}}</ref>
In addition to his books, ''Cherotic Magic'', ''Art of a Shaman'', ''Chapped Lap'',''Skin Passion'' and numerous other self-published pieces, Moore was widely published in various art and other periodicals. In artist Pamela Kay Walker's book, ''Moving Over the Edge,'' Moore is one of the artists featured as having "greatly impacted me and many people through their artistic expression and their lives."<ref>{{cite news |last=Walker |first=Pamela Kay. |title=''Moving Over the Edge: Artists with Disabilities Take the Leap'' |publisher= Michael Horton Media. Davis, California. pp. 54-69. (2005) {{ISBN|0-9771505-2-6}}.}}</ref>
Moore's award-winning video works have shown throughout North America, and in 2001 he began producing shows for Berkeley's [[public access]] channel, Berkeley Community Media, Channel 28.<ref>{{cite news |last=Burke |first=Stoney |title=''Weapon: Mouth Adventures in the Free Speech Zone'' |publisher=Regent Press, 2014. pg. 192. {{ISBN|978-1587902727}}}}</ref> His shows continue to play several times each week.
In 2011, Moore launched his online performance and video retrospective on [[Vimeo]]. At the same time he created the ''EROART'' group featuring videos by eroart artists from across the world.
Frank Moore's ''Web of All Possibilities'' features a growing archive of his audio, video, visual and written work, as well as the work of other artists. He founded Love Underground Visionary Revolution (LUVeR) in 1999, a webstation combining live streaming and on-demand libraries of audio and video programming,<ref name="Sant 2011. pg. 105"/> described by Moore as a "non-corporate, d.i.y., totally uncensored, noncommercial, nonprofit internet-only communal collective with 24-hour 'live' programming (by amazing people) with 'no-limits' content." LUVeR ran until 2012.
In 2006, Moore announced his candidacy for the 2008 election for President of the United States.<ref name="Wikinews">{{cite news |url=https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Wikinews_interviews_Frank_Moore,_independent_candidate_for_US_President |newspaper=[[Wikinews]] |title=Wikinews_interviews_Frank_Moore,_independent_candidate_for_US_President|date=1 March 2008}}</ref> He became a qualified [[write-in]] candidate in 25 states. His campaign was responsible for reforming the write-in candidate qualifications and procedures in many states. His platform videos are available on [[YouTube]].
Moore also hosted his regular internet show, ''Frank Moore's Shaman's Den''. Moore describes it as a show that "will arouse, inspire, move, threaten you, not with sound bites, but with a two-hour (usually longer) feast of live streaming video. You might get an in-studio concert of bands from around the world...or poetry reading...or an in-depth conversation about politics, art, music, and LIFE with extremely dangerous people! But then you may see beautiful women naked dancing erotically. You never know, because you are in ''The Shaman's Den'' with Frank Moore." Video and audio archives of all of these ''Shaman's Den'' shows are available online.
Frank Moore died of pneumonia on October 14, 2013.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/sanfrancisco/iconic-bay-area-performance-artist-frank-moore-dies-tribute-planned-in-oakland/Content?oid=2608053 |title=Iconic Bay Area performance artist Frank Moore dies; tribute planned in Oakland |last=Echavaria |first=Vince |publisher=San Francisco Examiner 10/21/13}}</ref> He performed regularly in the San Francisco Bay Area up until his death.
==Influence and Legacy== Performance artist [[Annie Sprinkle]] considers Moore one of her teachers,<ref>{{cite news |last=Sprinkle |first=A. |title=''Post-porn modernist: my 25 years as a multimedia whore'' |publisher=Cleis Press, 1998. {{ISBN|1-57344-039-6}}}}</ref> and Moore performed with a host of performance and underground punk figures since the 1970s.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Boulware |first1=Jack |last2=Tudor |first2=Silke |title=''Gimme Something Better: The Profound, Progressive, and Occasionally Pointless History of Bay Area Punk from Dead Kennedys to Green Day'' |publisher=Penguin Books, 2009. pg. 306 {{ISBN|978-0143113805}}}}</ref> including Barbara Smith, Linda Sibio, [[The Feederz]], and [[Dirk Dirksen]] - The Pope of Punk.
Frank Moore's life and art are now being documented in a web video series called ''Let Me Be Frank''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.traileraddict.com/let-me-be-frank-2016/trailer |title=Trailer for ''Let Me Be Frank'' |website=on TrailerAddict.com}}</ref>
As of September 2017, Frank Moore's work is now being archived at the [[Bancroft Library]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Frank Moore archives – 1st delivery to UCB Bancroft Library made today! |url=http://eroplay.org/?p=46 |website=The Frank Moore Archives |accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> The collection is titled “Frank Moore papers, approximately 1970-2013.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Frank Moore Papers|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/search?style=oac4;ff=0;institution=UC%20Berkeley::Bancroft%20Library;query=frank%20moore;idT=UCb24074536x|website=Online Archive of California|accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref>
In April 2018, the [[Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive]] (BAMPFA) accepted two of Frank’s oil paintings into their permanent collection: ''Mariah'' (1977), and ''Patti Smith'' (1979).<ref>{{cite web|title=BAMPFA Art Collection Search – Mariah|url=https://webapps.cspace.berkeley.edu/bampfa/search/search/?maxresults=1&displayType=full&idnumber=2018.16.2|website=Berkeley.edu|accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BAMPFA Art Collection Search – Patti Smith|url=https://webapps.cspace.berkeley.edu/bampfa/search/search/?maxresults=1&displayType=full&idnumber=2018.16.1|website=Berkeley.edu|accessdate=13 August 2018}}</ref>

revision.text:
The '''Gävle Symphony Orchestra''' ('''Gävle symfoniorkester''') is a Swedish [[symphony orchestra]] based in [[Gävle]].
Founded in 1912, the orchestra initially gave its concerts in the Gävle theatre and Mariners' Church. In 1998, a purpose-built concert hall was constructed overlooking the [[Gavleån]].
As of 2010, the orchestra had 52 permanent members.
Among its discography are recordings of Tre Dalmålningar by [[Oskar Lindberg (composer)|Oskar Lindberg]], [[Xaver Scharwenka]]'s Symphony in C minor, symphonic poems by [[Franz Berwald]]; orchestral works by Gustaf Bengtsson, [[Oscar Byström (composer)|Oscar Byström]]'s Symphony in D minor, [[Jacob Adolf Hägg]]'s Nordic Symphony; orchestral music by [[Armas Järnefelt]], [[Otto Olsson]]'s Symphony in G minor, [[Kurt Atterberg]]'s violin and piano concertos; a concert live from the [[Concertgebouw (Amsterdam)|Amsterdam Concertgebouw]] with works by [[Grieg]], [[Svendsen]] and [[Shostakovich]] with [[Carlos Spierer]], [[Rosa Arnold]], [[Enrica Ciccarelli]]; [[Sven-David Sandström]]'s piano concerto. [[File:Konserthuset Gävle 2013.jpg|thumb|240 px|right|Gävle concert hall, home of the Gävle Symphony Orchestra]]
Since 1 July 2012, Jaime Martín has served as the orchestra's artistic adviser, and on 1 July 2013, he became the orchestra's principal conductor. His initial contract is for 4 years.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.gavle.se/Kommun--politik/Press-och-informationsmaterial/Pressmeddelanden/Pressmeddelandemapp/-New-principal-conductor-for-the-Gavle-Symphony-Orchestra/ | title=New principal conductor for the Gävle Symphony Orchestra | publisher=Gävle kommun (City of Gävle) | date=11 June 2012 | accessdate=2013-12-26}}</ref>
==Principal conductors== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Ruben Liljefors]], 1912-1931 * Ludvig Mowinckel, 1931-1934 * Sten Frykberg, 1934-1939 * Sixten Eckerberg, 1936 * Eric Bengtson, 1939-1948 * [[Stig Westerberg]], 1949-1953 * Siegfried Naumann, 1953-1954 * Gunnar Staern, 1954-1963 * Carl Rune Larsson, 1963-1967 * Rainer Miedel, 1968-1975 * ''(No chief conductor 1975-81)'' * Göran W Nilson, 1981-1984 * Doron Salomon, 1984-1990 * Hannu Koivula, 1991-1996 * Carlos Spierer, 1997-2000 * Petri Sakari, 2000-2006 * [[Robin Ticciati]], 2006-2009 * [[Jaime Martín]], 2013-present {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gavlesymfoniorkester.se Official website of the orchestra]

page.title: History of Italian Art of the Twentieth Century

revision.text:
'''''History of Italian Art of the Twentieth Century''''' (Storia dell'arte italiana del '900) is an art encyclopedia written between 1981 and 2010 by critic and art historian [[Giorgio Di Genova]] published by Edizioni Bora in [[Bologna]].
== Description == The encyclopedia, which discusses both [[painting]] and [[sculpture]], traces the critical profiles of artists who have characterized twentieth century [[Italian art]]. The content is organized on a biographical basis, although the text is composed of historical-themed chapters and not individual entries. The distribution of content between the various volumes takes place on a generational basis: each volume deals with facts and personalities that have characterized the different generations of artists, divided by decades: from the "Historical Masters generation" (of which the personalities born in the course Of the nineteenth century but still active in the twentieth century) comes the "forties generation" (of which artists born between 1940 and 1949). This entirely peculiar setting has the advantage of creating in the vast biographical panorama the analyzed criteria for distinguishing and organizing objective and controlled content.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=TfN73TARh0sC&pg=PA59&dq=di+genova+%22storia+dell'arte+italiana+del+'900%22&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCTgKahUKEwj7h7uyiuzGAhUCjnIKHTGWDXk#v=onepage&q=di%20genova%20%22storia%20dell'arte%20italiana%20del%20'900%22&f=false|title=Come studiare l'arte contemporanea|last=Crispolti|first=Enrico|date=2010|publisher=Donzelli Editore|isbn=9788860363749|language=it}}</ref>
== Drafting == In [[Geneva]], at the beginning of the eighties, Genoa began writing the contents of those which later became volumes 4, 5 and 6 on three exhibitions on Italian artists born in the twenties (1981), ten years (1982) and First decade (1985) of the twentieth century. Since 1993, publisher Bora of Bologna has started publishing encyclopedia volumes.
In 1999 Di Genova was among the founders of MAGI '900, the museum in Pieve di Cento, which aims to set up an anthological collection of 20th century Italian art, becoming the museum's equivalent to the encyclopedic contents of the ''History of Art.''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=zGbK_iD0ZMsC&pg=PA225&dq=di+genova+%22storia+dell'arte+italiana+del+'900%22&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwATgKahUKEwj7h7uyiuzGAhUCjnIKHTGWDXk#v=onepage&q=di%20genova%20%22storia%20dell'arte%20italiana%20del%20'900%22&f=false|title=Cultura e competitività. Per un nuovo agire imprenditoriale|last=cultura|first=Osservatorio impresa e|date=2003|publisher=Rubbettino Editore|isbn=9788849807332|language=it}}</ref>
== Contents == The work is divided into seven volumes. It features fivethousand artists, with over thirty-five thousand names listed in the analytical index. There are reproductions, in color and black and white, of about tenthousand works.
The work plan is as follows: * Volume 1: ''Generating Historical Masters'' ** Tomo I (1993, {{ISBN|88-85345-24-7}} ) ** Tomo II (1994, {{ISBN|88-85345-36-0}} ) ** Tomo III (1995, {{ISBN|88-85345-43-3}} ) * Volume 2: ''First Decade Generation'' (1996, {{ISBN|88-85345-55-7}} ) * Volume 3: ''Generation Years Ten'' (1990, {{ISBN|88-85345-00-X}} ) * Volume 4: 20th Century ''Generation'' (1991, {{ISBN|88-85345-10-7}} ) * Volume 5: ''Generation of the Thirties'' (2000, {{ISBN|88-85345-81-6}} ) * Volume 6: ''Generation of the 40s'' ** Tomo I (2007, {{ISBN|978-88-88600-39-0}} ) ** Tomo II (2009, {{ISBN|978-88-88600-54-3}} ) * Volume 7: ''General Index'' (2010, {{ISBN|978-88-88600-55-0}} )
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Italian art]] [[Category:Italian books]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox book | name = Hot Art:
Chasing Thieves and Detectives through the Secret World of Stolen Art | image = Hot Art book cover.jpg | caption = First edition cover of Canadian release | author = Joshua Knelman | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Canada | subject = [[True crime]] | genre = non-fiction, bookGoodreads, [http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/12152998-hot-art ''Hot Art''], Book review, Retrieved November 23, 2012 | publisher = [[Douglas & McIntyre]] | pub_date = September 2, 2011 | media_type = Print (hardback and paperback) | pages = 316 pp. | isbn = 9781553658917 | oclc = }} '''''Hot Art: Chasing Thieves and Detectives through the Secret World of Stolen Art''''' is a non-fiction book, written by [[Canadian writer]] '''Joshua Knelman''', first published in September 2011 by [[Douglas & McIntyre]]. In the book, the author chronicles his four-year investigation into the world of international [[art theft]].Laycock, Holly, [http://www.propellermag.com/Summer2012/LaycockKnelmanSummer12.html Staying Under the Radar], Propeller Magazine, Retrieved November 21, 2012 Knelman traveled from [[Cairo]] to [[NYC|New York]], London, Montreal, and Los Angeles compiling his book; which has been called "A major work of investigative journalism", and "a globetrotting mystery filled with cunning and eccentric characters."Douglas & McIntyre, [http://www.dmpibooks.com/book/hot-art ''Hot Art''], Book review, Retrieved November 21, 2012 ==Awards and honours== ''Hot Art'' received the 2012 "[[Arthur Ellis Award]]" for "Best Crime Nonfiction".Crime Writers of Canada, [http://crimewriterscanada.com/awards/arthur-ellis-awards/current-contest/winners#Non-fiction 2012 Arthur Ellis Awards Winners], Best Crime Non-fiction, Retrieved November 21, 2012 The book also received the 2012 "[[Edna Staebler Award]] for [[Creative Non-Fiction]]".Faculty of Arts, November 7, 2012, [http://www.wlu.ca/news_detail.php?grp_id=2529&nws_id=10049 Joshua Knelman wins the 2012 Edna Staebler Award], ''Wilfrid Laurier University'', Headlines (News Releases), Retrieved November 21, 2012 ==See also== *[[List of Edna Staebler Award recipients]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *Upper Hudson Library System, [https://archive.is/20130416014153/http://vufind.uhls.org/vufind/Record/903313/Excerpt ''Hot Art''], Excerpt, Retrieved November 21, 2012 {{Edna Staebler Award}} [[Category:Canadian non-fiction books]] [[Category:2011 books]] [[Category:Art crime]] [[Category:Douglas & McIntyre books]] {{crime-book-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Jacob's Ladder | image = Jacobsladderposter.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Adrian Lyne]] | producer = [[Alan Marshall (producer)|Alan Marshall]] | writer = [[Bruce Joel Rubin]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Tim Robbins]] * [[Elizabeth Peña]] * [[Danny Aiello]] }} | music = [[Maurice Jarre]] | cinematography = [[Jeffrey L. Kimball]] | editing = [[Tom Rolf]] | studio = [[Carolco Pictures]] | distributor = [[TriStar Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1990|11|02}} | runtime = 113 minutes{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/jacobs-ladder-1970-3 | title=''Jacob's Ladder'' (18) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 6, 1990 | accessdate=October 2, 2016}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $25 millionTime Golden, [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/arts/film-up-jacob-s-ladder-and-into-the-hell-of-a-veteran-s-psyche.html Up 'Jacob's Ladder' And Into the Hell Of a Veteran's Psyche], ''The New York Times'', October 28, 1990 | gross = $26.1 million{{mojo title|jacobsladder|Jacob's Ladder}} }} '''''Jacob's Ladder''''' is a 1990 American [[psychological horror]] film directed by [[Adrian Lyne]], produced by [[Alan Marshall (producer)|Alan Marshall]], written by [[Bruce Joel Rubin]] and starring [[Tim Robbins]], [[Elizabeth Peña]], and [[Danny Aiello]]. The film's protagonist, Jacob, is a [[Vietnam veteran]] whose experiences prior to and during the war result in strange, fragmentary visions and bizarre hallucinations that continue to haunt him. As his ordeal worsens, Jacob desperately attempts to figure out the truth. ''Jacob's Ladder'' was made by [[Carolco Pictures]] ten years after being written by Rubin. It drew from several inspirations for its story and effects, including the short film ''[[An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge (film)|An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge]]'' and the paintings of [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]]. Though only moderately successful upon release, the film garnered a [[Cult film|cult following]] and became a source of influence for various other works such as the horror video game franchise ''[[Silent Hill]]''. A remake, also titled ''[[Jacob's Ladder (2019 film)|Jacob's Ladder]]'', is currently in production for a planned 2019 release. ==Plot== On 6 October 1971, an American [[combat medic]], Jacob Singer, is with the [[1st Cavalry Division (United States)|1st Air Cavalry Division]], deployed in a village in Vietnam's [[Mekong Delta]], when his close-knit unit comes under sudden attack. As many of Jacob's comrades are killed or wounded, others exhibit abnormal behavior with some suffering [[catatonia]], convulsions, and seizures. Jacob flees into the jungle, only to be bayoneted by an unseen assailant. Jacob awakens in the [[New York City Subway]], where an inexplicably locked subway station exit results in him almost being hit by a train. The year is 1975, he works as a postal clerk, and lives in a rundown apartment in [[Brooklyn]] with his girlfriend, Jezzie. Jacob misses his old family and experiences visions of them, especially the youngest of his sons, Gabe, who had died in an accident before the war. He is increasingly beset by disturbing experiences and apparitions, including glimpses of faceless vibrating figures, and narrowly escapes being run over by a pursuing car. At a party thrown by friends, he appears to witness an enormous creature penetrating Jezzie before he collapses with a dangerous fever. First-person perspective apparent [[Flashback (psychology)|flashbacks]] to his time in Vietnam show Jacob, badly wounded, being discovered by American soldiers before being evacuated under fire in a helicopter. One of Jacob's former platoon mates, Paul, contacts him to reveal he is suffering from similar experiences but is immediately killed when his car explodes. Commiserating after the funeral, other surviving members of the platoon confess that they have all been experiencing horrifying hallucinations. Believing that they are suffering the effects of a military experiment performed on them without their knowledge or consent, they hire a lawyer to investigate. However the lawyer quits the case after reading military files documenting that the soldiers were never in combat and were discharged for psychological reasons. Jacob's comrades soon back down while Jacob suspects they have been threatened into doing so. He is abducted by suited men who try to intimidate him. Jacob fights them and escapes but is injured and nearly paralyzed in the process. He is taken to a nightmarish hospital, where he is told he has been killed and this is home, but his [[chiropractor]] friend Louis comes to his rescue and heals him. Louis quotes the 14th-century [[Christian mysticism|Christian mystic]], [[Meister Eckhart]]:
Eckhart saw [[Hell]] too. He said: "The only thing that burns in Hell is the part of you that won't let go of life, your memories, your attachments. They burn them all away. But they're not punishing you", he said. "They're freeing your soul. So, if you're frightened of dying and ... you're holding on, you'll see [[devil]]s tearing your life away. But if you've made your peace, then the devils are really [[angel]]s, freeing you from the earth."
Jacob is approached by a distressed man who was seen treating his wound in a [[Medical evacuation|medevac]] helicopter and who also dragged him away from Paul's burning car. Introducing himself as Michael Newman, he tells a story of having been a chemist with [[Chemical Corps|the Army's chemical warfare division]] where he designed a drug he called the Ladder, which when ingested massively increased aggression. To test its effectiveness, a dose was secretly given to Jacob's unit before the battle, causing some of them to turn on each other in a homicidal frenzy. Michael's revelation triggers a vision of his wounding in Vietnam, in which he sees that his attacker was a fellow American soldier. Jacob returns to his family's home, where he finds Gabe, who takes him by the hand and leads him up the staircase into a bright light. In a [[triage]] tent in 1971, military doctors declare Jacob dead. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Tim Robbins]] as Jacob "Professor" Singer * [[Elizabeth Peña]] as Jezebel "Jezzie" Pipkin * [[Danny Aiello]] as Louis "Louie" Denardo * [[Matt Craven]] as Michael Newman * [[Pruitt Taylor Vince]] as Paul Gruneger * [[Jason Alexander]] as Mr. Geary, the lawyer * [[Patricia Kalember]] as Sarah * [[Eriq La Salle]] as Frank * [[Ving Rhames]] as George * Brian Tarantina as Doug * Anthony Alessandro as Rod * Brent Hinkley as Jerry * [[S. Epatha Merkerson]] as Elsa * [[Kyle Gass]] as Tony * [[Lewis Black]] as Jacob's doctor * [[Perry Lang]] as Jacob's assailant * [[Macaulay Culkin]] (uncredited) as Gabe Singer {{div col end}} ==Production== {{quote box|quote=The horror of the movie would be in the revelation that hope is hell's final torment, that life is a dream that ends over and over with the final truth: that life was never real, that we are all creatures trapped in eternal suffering and damnation.|source=–[[Bruce Joel Rubin]]Paul Meehan, ''Horror Noir: Where Cinema's Dark Sisters Meet'', McFarland, 2011 (p.259).|width=30%}} The film's title refers to the Biblical story of [[Jacob's Ladder]], or the dream of a meeting place between [[Heaven]] and Earth ([[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] 28:12). Its little-known alternate title is ''Dante's Inferno'', in a reference to ''[[Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]'' by [[Dante Alighieri]].John Flowers, Paul Frizler, ''Psychotherapists on Film, 1899-1999: A Worldwide Guide to Over 5000 Films, Volume 1'', McFarland, 2004 (p.309).Pamela Jaye Smith, ''Inner Drives'', Michael Wiese Productions, 2005 (p.217).Eric G. Wilson, ''Secret Cinema: Gnostic Vision in Film'', Bloomsbury, 2006 (p.123). Screenwriter and co-producer [[Bruce Joel Rubin]] perceived the film as a modern interpretation of the ''[[Bardo Thodol|Liberation Through Hearing During the Intermediate State]]'', the [[Tibet]]an Book of the Dead.{{cite news | title = Adrian Lyne Met A Metaphysical Challenge | first = John | last = Hartl | url = http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19901101&slug=1101695 | work = [[The Seattle Times]] | date = 1990-11-01 | accessdate = 2010-02-06 }}{{cite news | title = FILM; Up 'Jacob's Ladder' And Into the Hell Of a Veteran's Psyche | first = Tim | last = Golden | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/28/arts/film-up-jacob-s-ladder-and-into-the-hell-of-a-veteran-s-psyche.html | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 1990-10-28 | accessdate = 2007-10-22 }} Rubin said: "The inspiration in a sense is my entire spiritual upbringing. Once you have a [[Buddhist meditation|meditative life]] you start to see that the world is really far different than what it appears to be. What appears to be finite is really couched in the infinite, and the infinite imbues everything in our lives."''Tricycle: The Buddhist Review - Volume 1'', Buddhist Ray, 1991 (p.77). Before writing his scripts for ''Jacob's Ladder'' and ''[[Ghost (1990 film)|Ghost]]'', which too was released in 1990, the Jewish-born Rubin spent two years in a [[Tibetan Buddhism|Tibetan Buddhist]] monastery in Nepal;Carrol Lee Fry, ''Cinema of the Occult: New Age, Satanism, Wicca, and Spiritualism in Film'', Associated University Presse, 2008 (p.77). previously, he has also written [[afterlife]]-themed ''[[Brainstorm (1983 film)|Brainstorm]]'' and ''[[Deadly Friend]]''. Rubin's work on ''Jacob's Ladder'' began in 1980, sparked by his nightmare in which he dreamt about being trapped in a subway. For several years, Rubin tried to sell the script, without success; [[Thom Mount]] of [[Universal Pictures]] said he "loved it, but it was not for his studio". Directors [[Michael Apted]], [[Sidney Lumet]] and [[Ridley Scott]] all expressed an interest in making the film, but still no major studio was ready to invest in Rubin's "too [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]]" stories as "Hollywood does not make [[List of ghost films|ghost movies]]". Eventually, after ''Deadly Friend'' was filmed by [[Wes Craven]] in 1986, Rubin's screenplays for both ''Jacob's Ladder'' and ''Ghost'' were picked by [[Paramount Pictures]]. In 1988, [[Adrian Lyne]], who described Rubin's work as "certainly one of the best scripts I've ever read", decided then to direct it instead of an adaptation of ''[[The Bonfire of the Vanities]]'' as he had originally planned (incidentally, [[Tom Hanks]], an actor originally considered by Lyne for the role of Jacob, ended up starring in ''Bonfire''). The ownership and policy changes at Paramount resulted in the cancellation of the project; the executives had doubts about the film's ending and the scenes taking place in Vietnam. The [[independent film]] studio [[Carolco Pictures]] decided to take over the production of ''Jacob's Ladder'', giving Lyne a greater creative control and a budget of $25 million. Rubin became the film's co-producer, along with [[Mario Kassar]], [[Alan Marshall (producer)|Alan Marshall]] and [[Andrew G. Vajna]]. {{quote box|quote=I can see why people didn't want to make it for so long. It reads like a novel, and it's very intimidating because it's written so descriptively. Bruce had these very literal images of heaven and hell that I didn't know how to bring off. How do you introduce a character with horns?|source=–[[Adrian Lyne]]|width=30%}} Lyne, who downplayed Rubin's "intimidating" [[Old Testament]] themes,Tom Ruffles, ''Ghost Images: Cinema of the Afterlife'', McFarland, 2004 (p.192). said that he prepared for making the film by watching "endless" documentary films about the war in Vietnam and reading "countless" chronicles of [[near-death experience]]s. The film's plot device of a long period of [[Time perception|subjective time]] passing in an instant has been explored by several authors. A particularly strong inspiration for both Rubin and Lyne was [[Robert Enrico]]'s 1962 short film ''[[An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge (film)|An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge]]'',Bruce Joel Rubin, ''Jacob's Ladder'', Applause Theatre & Cinema Books, 1990 one of Lyne's favourite movies, which was in turn based on [[Ambrose Bierce]]'s 1890 short story [[An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge|of the same title]]. Cast in the role of Jacob, [[Tim Robbins]] said the film presented for him "a great opportunity to go in a different direction. I love doing comedy, but I know I can do other things as well." The film's military advisor was Vietnam veteran Captain [[Dale Dye]],Almar Haflidason, [http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2001/10/15/dale_dye_2001_2_interview.shtml Dale Dye: Part 2 - Stop Whining at Me!], BBC, October 2003 who provided a five-day [[Recruit training|boot camp]] military training for the actors playing soldiers in the Vietnam storyline (including Robbins, [[Pruitt Taylor Vince]], [[Eriq La Salle]] and [[Ving Rhames]]). The war scenes were filmed in the [[Puerto Rico]] area of [[Vega Baja]], featuring the [[UH-1 Iroquois|UH-1]] helicopters provided by the [[Puerto Rico National Guard]]. All of the film's special effect sequences were filmed in camera, with no use of post production effects. In several scenes of ''Jacob's Ladder'', Lyne used a [[body horror]] technique in which an actor is recorded shaking his head around at a low [[frame rate]], resulting in horrifically fast motion when played back. In the Special Edition's commentary track, Lyne said he was inspired by the art of the painter [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]] when developing the effect.{{cite web|url=http://www.widerscreenings.com/jacobsladder.html |title=Jacob's Ladder |publisher=Widerscreenings.com |date=|accessdate=2012-06-18}} In his screenplay, Rubin used traditional imagery of demons and hell. However, Lyne decided to use images similar to [[thalidomide]] deformities to achieve a greater shock effect. After many heated arguments, Lyne managed to convert Rubin to his vision. Lyne and Rubin used the works of the artist [[H. R. Giger]] and the photographers [[Diane Arbus]] and [[Joel-Peter Witkin]] for inspiration; another influence came from the [[Brothers Quay]]'s 1986 [[stop motion]] short film ''[[Street of Crocodiles]]''. {{quote box|quote=Vietnam was really a means to an end. It was a plot device rather than something we were trying to make a huge issue of.|source=–[[Alan Marshall (producer)|Alan Marshall]]|width=30%}} In the film, Jacob is told by Michael that the horrific events he experienced on his final day in Vietnam were the product of an experimental drug called "the Ladder", which was used on troops without their knowledge. At the end of the film, a message is displayed saying that reports of testing of BZ, [[NATO]] code for a [[deliriant]] and [[hallucinogen]] known as [[3-Quinuclidinyl benzilate|3-quinuclidinyl benzilate]], on U.S. soldiers during the Vietnam War were denied by the [[United States Department of Defense|Pentagon]]. Lyne said a part of the inspiration for this motif was [[Martin A. Lee]]'s book ''[[Acid Dreams: The CIA, LSD and Sixties Rebellion]]'', but noted that "nothing in the book suggests that the drug BZ — a super-hallucinogen that has a tendency to elicit [[Mania|maniac behavior]] — was used on U.S. troops." According to Lyne's audio commentary, [[test screening]]s indicated that the initial version of the film was overwhelming for the audience. In response, about 20 minutes of disturbing scenes, mostly from the last third of the film, were removed from the final cut. ==Release== ===Theatrical release=== ''Jacob's Ladder'' opened on November 2, 1990, distributed by [[TriStar Pictures]]. ''Jacob's Ladder: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack'' with the music by [[Maurice Jarre]] was released by [[Varèse Sarabande]] in 1993.{{cite web|author=Maurice Jarre |url=https://www.amazon.com/Jacobs-Ladder-Original-Picture-Soundtrack/dp/B0000014RW |title=Jacob's Ladder: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack: Music |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-23}} Rubin's companion book, released by [[Hal Leonard Corporation|Applause Theater Book Publishers]] on the same day as the film, features a final draft of the screenplay, including the [[deleted scene]]s, and his essay on making of the screenplay and the film. ===Home media=== The Special Edition [[DVD]] was released by [[Artisan Entertainment]] on July 14, 1998, containing three deleted scenes ("Jezzie's Transformation", "The Antidote" and "The Train Station") along with several other special features, such as audio commentary by Adrian Lyne and a 26-minute [[making-of]] documentary "Building ''Jacob's Ladder''". On September 14, 2010, the film was released on [[Blu-ray Disc]] by [[Lions Gate Entertainment]] and retains all of the special features of the DVD version, along with two [[Trailer (promotion)|trailer]]s, omitting only a TV spot that came with the DVD.R.L. Shaffer, [http://uk.ign.com/articles/2010/09/14/jacobs-ladder-blu-ray-review Jacob's Ladder Blu-ray Review], IGN, September 14, 2010 ==Reception== ===Box office=== The film took the number one spot at the weekend [[box office]] in North America, garnering ticket sales of $7.5 million from 1,052 screens.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-05/entertainment/ca-3119_1_ticket-sales |title='Jacob's Ladder' Climbs to Top of Ticket Sales. - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2000-08-17 |accessdate=2013-06-28 |first=Pat H. |last=Broeske}} However, the attendance dropped fast and its overall domestic box office result was only $26,118,851. ===Critical reception=== According to aggregate website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], 69% of reviews of the film have been positive based on 61 reviews.{{cite web| url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/jacobs_ladder/ | title = Jacob's Ladder (1990) | publisher = ''[[Rotten Tomatoes]]'' | accessdate = 2010-04-16 }} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "C-" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite web |url=https://m.cinemascore.com |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com}} [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' wrote that watching it left him "reeling with turmoil and confusion, with feelings of sadness and despair," and called it a "thoroughly painful and depressing experience — but, it must be said, one that has been powerfully written, directed and acted." He awarded the film three and a half out of a possible four stars.{{cite news| url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19901102/REVIEWS/11020301/1023 | title = Jacob's Ladder | last = Ebert | first = Roger | date = 1990-11-02 | publisher = ''Rogerebert.suntimes.com'' | accessdate = 2010-04-16 }} [[Janet Maslin]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that this "slick, riveting, viscerally scary film about what in other hands would be a decidedly unsalable subject, namely [[death]]," is "both quaint and devastating."Janet Maslin, [https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9C0CE7D8143CF931A35752C1A966958260 Movie Review - Jacob s Ladder - Review/Film; It's Scary, Yes, and Death Has a Role], ''The New York Times'', November 2, 1990 However, [[Desson Thomson]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' felt disappointed with the film that is "ultimately flat on its [[Surrealism|surrealistic]] face, the victim of too many fake-art sequences."Desson Howe, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/videos/jacobsladderrhowe_a0b2b5.htm 'Jacob's Ladder' (R)], ''Washington Post'', November 02, 1990 [[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' wrote that "''Jacob's Ladder'' is so 'dark' it sucks Robbins right down with it. By the time Jacob is being strapped to a bed and wheeled down a hospital corridor strewn with bloody limbs, it's hard to care whether the [[Orwellian]] image is a hallucination or not. You just want out."Owen Gleiberman, [http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,318521,00.html Jacob's Ladder (1990)], EW.com, Nov 02, 1990 [[Kim Newman]] called the film "effectively the blunt remake" of ''[[Carnival of Souls]]''. According to [[IGN]]'s review of the DVD release in 2004, "After movies like ''[[Seven (1995 film)|Se7en]]'', it may not pack the same subtle horror for today's audiences it did when it was first released, but it's still a great film."Mike Drucker, [http://uk.ign.com/articles/2004/11/08/jacobs-ladder Jacob's Ladder: The living nightmare of a movie has a pretty decent DVD.], IGN, November 8, 2004 IGN's review of ''Jacob's Ladder''{{'}}s 2010 Blu-ray release called it is "an emotionally poignant, creepy horror masterpiece." According to ''[[Slant Magazine]]'', ''Jacob's Ladder'' is "a bizarrely cohesive hybrid of war movie, character study, [[art film]], and horror flick" and "the very act of watching the film is so emotionally draining that the viewer leaves the film feeling worked-in; the thought of repeat viewings is daunting yet insatiable."{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/dvd/review/jacobs-ladder/1807 |title=Jacob's Ladder | DVD Review |publisher=Slant Magazine |date=2010-09-14 |accessdate=2013-06-28}} [[John Kenneth Muir]] called the film's nightmarish hospital scene "one of the most terrifying moments in all of 1990s horror cinema." Muir further wrote: "In its musings about death, about the end we all fear'', Jacob's Ladder'' proves a deeply affecting and meaningful motion picture. After a screening, you'll immediately want to hug the people you love and then go outside and breathe the fresh air, or otherwise affirm your very existence."John Kenneth Muir, ''Horror Films of the 1990s'', McFarland, 2011 (p.105). Rubin's script was included on the list of "Hollywood's ten best unproduced screenplays" by ''American Film'' magazine in 1983. In 1991, ''Jacob's Ladder'' was nominated at [[Horror Hall of Fame]] II for best horror film, losing to ''[[The Silence of the Lambs (film)|The Silence of the Lambs]]''. The film was also featured in [[Bravo (U.S. TV channel)|Bravo]]'s 2004 documentary miniseries ''[[The 100 Scariest Movie Moments]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.bravotv.com/The_100_Scariest_Movie_Moments/index.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071030070540/http://www.bravotv.com/The_100_Scariest_Movie_Moments/index.shtml |archivedate=2007-10-30 |title=The 100 Scariest Movie Moments: 100 Scariest Moments in Movie History - Official Bravo TV Site |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=|accessdate=2013-06-28}} and in the 2009 book ''[[1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die]]''. In 2013, the [[Jacob Burns Film Center]] Projectionist Andrew Robinson chose it as his favourite scary movie.{{cite web |url=http://blog.burnsfilmcenter.org/halloween-countdown-day-8-jacobs-ladder/ |title=Halloween Countdown – Day 8: Jacob's Ladder » Jacob Burns Film Center Blog |publisher=Blog.burnsfilmcenter.org |date=2013-10-26 |accessdate=2014-07-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728200336/http://blog.burnsfilmcenter.org/halloween-countdown-day-8-jacobs-ladder/ |archivedate=July 28, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} ==Legacy== ''Jacob's Ladder'' greatly inspired the horror franchise ''[[Silent Hill]]'',John Gaudiosi, [https://www.forbes.com/sites/johngaudiosi/2012/11/02/resident-evil-and-silent-hill-producer-samuel-hadida-talks-wolfenstein-and-onimusha-movies/ Resident Evil And Silent Hill Producer Samuel Hadida Talks Wolfenstein And Onimusha Movies], Forbes, 11/02/2012 including the video games ''[[Silent Hill (video game)|Silent Hill]]'' (1999),Bernard Perron, ''Silent Hill: The Terror Engine'', University of Michigan Press, 2012 (p. 55-56). ''[[Silent Hill 2]]'' (2001),[http://uk.ign.com/articles/2001/08/17/interview-with-silent-hill-2s-artist-takayoshi-sato Interview with Silent Hill 2',s Artist Takayoshi Sato], IGN, August 17, 2001 ''[[Silent Hill 3]]'' (2003),[http://uk.ign.com/articles/2002/06/12/silent-hill-3-interview Silent Hill 3 Interview], IGN, June 12, 2002 ''[[Silent Hill 4: The Room]]'' (2004),{{cite news| url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/collective/A3066879| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071227080553/http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/collective/A3066879| archivedate = 2007-12-27| title = Silent Hill 4: The Room| author = Daniel Etherington| work = [[bbc.co.uk]]| date = 2004-10-01| accessdate = 2007-06-09}} and ''[[Silent Hill: Homecoming]]'' (2007),{{cite web|last=Grayson |first=Vincent |url=http://www.shacknews.com/article/52765/silent-hill-5-interview-jasons |title=Silent Hill 5 Interview: Jason's Philosophy, Jacob's Ladder, and Pyramid Head |publisher=Shacknews.com |date=|accessdate=2012-06-18}} as well as the series' 2006 [[Silent Hill (film)|film adaptation]] by [[Christophe Gans]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bloody-disgusting.com/interview/219 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328090017/http://bloody-disgusting.com/interview/219 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-03-28 |title=Interview Silent Hill: Director Christophe Gans |publisher=Bloody Disgusting |date=|accessdate=2012-06-18}} The film's influence on their works was recognised by [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]], writer of the 2011 TV series ''[[American Horror Story: Asylum]]'',[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/03/jessica-lange-the-name-game_n_2402373.html Jessica Lange Sings 'The Name Game': 'American Horror Story: Asylum' Goes Musical], HUFFPOST TV, 01/03/2013 and by [[Shinji Mikami]], director of the 2014 video game ''[[The Evil Within]]''.Lucy O'Brien, [http://uk.ign.com/articles/2013/05/06/the-movie-every-survival-horror-fan-should-watch "Am I dying, Louie?"], IGN, May 16, 2013. [[Kim Manners]] prepared for directing ''[[The X-Files]]'' episode "[[Grotesque (The X-Files)|Grotesque]]" by listening to the music from ''Jacob's Ladder''.Brian Lowry, ''The Truth is Out There: The Official Guide to the X-Files'', Harper Prism, 1995 (p.158). The music video for the 2010 song "[[Nightmare (Avenged Sevenfold song)|Nightmare]]" by [[Avenged Sevenfold]] is a [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to the famous hospital scene from the film, chosen because the band's deceased drummer [[The Rev]] was a fan of the film. ''Jacob's Ladder'' as a film is directly referred to in ''Silent Hill 2'' and especially ''Silent Hill 3''.{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/features/behind-mysteries-of-silent-hill |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130219221845/http://www.1up.com/features/behind-mysteries-of-silent-hill |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-19 |title=Behind the Many Mysteries of Silent Hill from |publisher=1UP.com |date= |accessdate=2013-06-28 }} Other references include the 2002 ''[[The Twilight Zone (2002 TV series)|The Twilight Zone]]'' episode "[[Night Route]]", the 2005 film ''[[Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit]]'', and the 2010 ''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[The Squirt and the Whale]]". [[Claytown Troupe]] used a [[Sample (music)|sample]] of Michael's quote 'It's a fast trip ... ' at the beginning of the track "Rainbow's Edge" in the 1991 album ''Out There''. [[UNKLE]] sampled dialogue from the film in their 1998 "[[Rabbit in Your Headlights]]" and again in 2003 in "Inside". [[VNV Nation]]'s track "Forsaken" from the 1998 album ''[[Praise the Fallen]]'' ends with the quotation from Eckhart. "Devils" from [[IVardensphere]]'s 2011 album ''APOK'' begins with the same quotation. A sample of Jacob's cry 'Stop it, you're killing me!' is used in "Next in Line" in [[Nevermore]]'s 1996 album ''[[The Politics of Ecstasy (album)|The Politics of Ecstasy]]''. Terminal Sect extensively sampled the film for their track "Where Angels Fall". The film's possible influence can be arguably seen in many other works ranging from [[M. Night Shyamalan]]'s 1999 hit psychological horror film ''[[The Sixth Sense]]''Charles Derry, ''Dark Dreams 2.0: A Psychological History of the Modern Horror Film from the 1950s to the 21st Century'', McFarland, 2009 (p.223). to [[Peter Arnett]]'s controversial 1998 [[CNN]] report "Valley of Death" about the 1970 [[Operation Tailwind]].Jerry Lembcke, ''CNN's Tailwind Tale: Inside Vietnam's Last Great Myth'', Rowman & Littlefield, 2003 (p.77). [[Jeff Millar]] of ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' wrote that [[Giuseppe Tornatore]]'s 1994 psychological thriller ''[[A Pure Formality]]'' uses the plot device of ''Jacob's Ladder'' mixed with several other sources.Jeff Millar, [http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/1995_1300653/pure-formality-so-pretentious-is-hurts.html 'Pure Formality' so pretentious is hurts], ''Houston Chronicle'', 10/06/1995 According to ''[[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]]'', [[Massy Tadjedin]]'s 2005 psychological thriller ''[[The Jacket]]'' "is a film for those who don't remember ''Jacob's Ladder'', perhaps for someone like Jacob himself", as it "resembles ''Jacob's Ladder'' too much for its own good".Brian W. Fairbanks, ''I Saw That Movie, Too: Selected Film Reviews'', 2005 (p.201). [[PopMatters]] called [[Michael Hurst]]'s 2006 horror film ''[[Room 6]]'' a "''Jacob's Ladder'' lift".Bill Gibron, [http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/room-6/ Room 6], PopMatters, 8 August 2006. ===Remake=== {{main|Jacob's Ladder (2019 film)}} The remake is currently in production, being directed by [[David M. Rosenthal (director)|David M. Rosenthal]] and written by Jeff Buhler and Sarah Thorp. The film stars [[Michael Ealy]], [[Jesse Williams (actor)|Jesse Williams]], [[Nicole Beharie]], [[Karla Souza]] and [[Guy Burnet]]. ==See also== * [[Conspiracy fiction]] and [[paranoid fiction]] * [[Cotard delusion]] * [[List of anti-war films]] * [[List of films featuring hallucinogens]] * [[List of nonlinear narrative films]] * [[Unethical human experimentation in the United States]] * [[Vietnam War in film]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0099871}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|jacobs_ladder}} * {{amg movie|25743}} * {{metacritic film|jacobs-ladder}} * [http://www.mrqe.com/movie_reviews/jacobs-ladder-m100045396 ''Jacob's Ladder''] at the [[Movie Review Query Engine]] {{Adrian Lyne}} {{good article}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jacob's Ladder}} [[Category:1990 films]] [[Category:1990 horror films]] [[Category:1990s war films]] [[Category:1990s thriller films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American war films]] [[Category:American supernatural horror films]] [[Category:American thriller films]] [[Category:Anti-war films]] [[Category:Carolco Pictures films]] [[Category:Death in art]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Fiction with unreliable narrators]] [[Category:Films about angels]] [[Category:Films directed by Adrian Lyne]] [[Category:Films scored by Maurice Jarre]] [[Category:Films set in 1971]] [[Category:Films set in 1975]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Films shot in New Jersey]] [[Category:Films shot in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Nonlinear narrative films]] [[Category:Psychological horror films]] [[Category:Religious horror films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Bruce Joel Rubin]] [[Category:Supernatural thriller films]] [[Category:Vietnam War films]] [[Category:1990s political films]]

{{Infobox dancer | name = Jessica Deahr | image = Jessica Deahr.jpg | caption = At the 2014 season announcement for Chicago Dance Crash | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1982|07|09}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, IL]], United States | occupation = Dancer, choreographer | years_active = 2004–present | nationality = American }} '''Jessica Anne Deahr''' (Chicago, 9 July 1982) is an American contemporary [[dancer]] and [[choreographer]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Helbig|first=Jack|title=Suburban choreographer didn't expect a career in dance|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20130530/entlife/705319989/|newspaper=Daily Herald|date=30 May 2013}}</ref> A dancer and first generation student of [[James Morrow (dance)|James Morrow]]'s "fusion technique" as part of the now defunct [[contemporary dance]] company "Instruments of Movement"<ref>{{cite web|last=Roberts|first=Michael|title=Chicago Dance Crash presents world premier of "Gotham City"|url=http://showbizchicago.com/2012/06/08/chicago-dance-crash-presents-world-premiere-of-gothem-city-june-8th-july15th/#.U0DCl17UUzA|publisher=Showbiz Chicago|accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref> (est. 2001),<ref>{{cite news|last=Molzahn|first=Laura|title=Instruments of Movement|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/instruments-of-movement/Content?oid=921154|newspaper=Chicago Reader|date=2 February 2006}}</ref> she was named Artistic Director of [[Chicago Dance Crash]] in November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nevin|first=Johnny|title=Dance Crash, Deahr and the Art of Connection|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/johnny-nevin/dance-crash-deahr-art_b_2564568.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref> Throughout her career, Deahr has performed, taught, and choreographed around the world.
==Early life and career== Deahr’s childhood training began in Arlington Heights, IL training primarily in jazz, ballet and hip hop. Upon earning a Bachelor of Arts degree in sociology with a minor in dance from [[Illinois Wesleyan University]], her early career continued as a trainee scholarship recipient of the Joel Hall Dance Center in [[Chicago]], IL<ref>[https://www.iwu.edu/magazine/2017/spring/deahr-dance.html "Guest choreographer Jessica Deahr ’04 stretches dance students to their limits." IWU Magazine 2017]</ref>.
In addition to teaching and modeling, as a professional dancer Deahr worked as a company member of James Morrow’s “Instruments of Movement” from 2007-2009 while guest performing for [[Harrison McEldowney]] and Frank Chaves among others. Combining both her creative range and commercial interests, Deahr performed for artists [[Nelly]], [[Vanilla Ice]], [[Jump Smokers]] and [[DJ Pauly D]] while contracting with [[Royal Caribbean International]] as both a dancer and ariel artist, performing domestically as well as across Europe, Asia and South America<ref>[http://www.dailyherald.com/article/20130530/entlife/705319989/ "Suburban Choreographer Didn't Expect a Career in Dance" Daily Herald 2013]</ref>.
==Chicago Dance Crash== Deahr’s first work with the Chicago-based contemporary company, [[Chicago Dance Crash]], was a supporting role in the 2007 production of ''Tiger Prawn: The Mountain Mover''.”<ref>{{cite news|last1=Almeida|first1=Fabrizio|title=Review: Tiger Prawn: The Mountain Mover/ Chicago Dance Crash|work=Newcity|date=July 7, 2007}}</ref> Quoted as remembering “I had a black sock over my head, was kind of in the background… didn’t care. I was just so excited to be part of something that seemed to fit. <ref>[https://vimeo.com/115537858 "History of Crash: 2001-2015" staff interviews]</ref>,” she continued guest work with the organization until being promoted to a company position by artistic director Kyle Vincent Terry in 2009. [[File:Jessica Deahr Fantasma.png|thumb|Deahr rehearsing a site-specific work. Photo by Kelly Stachura]]
Having successfully freelanced as a choreographer and upon Terry’s retirement, Deahr was named the company’s resident choreographer at the end of 2011<ref>{{cite web|last=Nevin|first=Johnny|title=Dance Crash, Deahr and the Art of Connection|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/johnny-nevin/dance-crash-deahr-art_b_2564568.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref>. As Crash operated without a formal artistic director for its 2012, tenth anniversary season, Deahr directed and choreographed the season’s signature production, ''Gotham City'' (inspired by the setting of [[Batman]] comic lore), which was later recognized by the [[Chicago Tribune]] as one of Chicago’s 10 best productions performed that year<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-12-13/entertainment/ct-ae-1216-best-dance-20121213_1_hubbard-street-dance-chicago-harris-theater-gustavo-ramirez-sansano "Dances from 2012 that Linger in Memory" Chicago Tribune, 2012]</ref>. She was internally acknowledged as the company’s artistic director throughout the 2012 season, with her promotion publicly announced to the audience at the company’s final performance of the year on November 17th<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zweR-qq2YrY&index=9&list=PLZa1beqMe01Zx3Z1YPJUxLHMagXF58e_e "Announcing our new Artistic Director" Chicago Dance Crash youtube channel]</ref>.
=== Artistic Director === Deahr is both the youngest and first female artistic director in the history of the organization. "Yeah I think it was kind of cool because when a company gets a new artistic director they come from somewhere 'here they are, meet them.' So that was slightly terrifying but also kind of cool because I knew them so well. So was cool to come... with a vengeance.<ref>[https://vimeo.com/115537858 "History of Crash: 2001-2015" staff interviews]</ref>"
As artistic director, Deahr has most notably expanded Crash’s Chicago-based educational outreach arm<ref>[http://urbangateways.org/qa-with-chicago-dance-crash-promoting-art-for-all-from-schools-to-the-modern-wing/ "Q+A with Chicago Dance Crash: Promoting Art for All, from Schools to the Modern Wing" Urban Gateways 2014]</ref> while taking the organization beyond the state of Illinois both nationally and internationally. Her full-length works including ''The Cotton Mouth Club,''<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zacher|first1=Scotty|title=Review: The Cotton Mouth Club (Chicago Dance Crash)|work=Chicago Theater Beat|date=May 27, 2013}}</ref> ''Evil & Good''<ref>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/theater/dance/ct-chicago-dance-crash-good-evil-ent-0711-20160710-column.html "Chicago Dance Crash plunges into ''Evil & Good''" Chicago Tribune July 9, 2016]</ref>, and ''The Bricklayers of Oz''<ref>[https://dancermusic.com/chicago-dance-crash-and-the-bricklayers-of-oz/ "Chicago Dance Crash and the Bricklayers of Oz" DancerMusic.com July 27, 2017]</ref> (inspired by [[The Land of Oz]] books by [[L. Frank Baum]]) have received critical acclaim while seeing extended tours. [[File:The Bricklayers of Oz1.jpg|thumb|Deahr performing in Dance Crash's production of "The Bricklayers of Oz"]]
==Critical Reception & Awards== Consistently, Deahr's work has been well received by American midwest and national press, starting with her first professional work on Crash earning the "New Voice Award" from the 2011 Dance Chicago Festival as well as being unveiled to the national public as “brash, funky, bright and street friendly in style.” by the Chicago Tribune<ref>[http://www.dancechicago.com/documents/CRASHSIDSMITHREVIE.pdf "Chicago Dance Crash offers ''RadioStars''" SeeChicagoDance.com 2010]</ref>. Taking an interest in Deahr's career, the [[Huffington Post]] noted in 2013 that “Deahr's versatility isn't at all an end in itself; it seems more to be her way of discovering an artistic expression that can go more places, because it's been more places. While many artists see an uncomfortable contradiction between artistic expression and audience approval, Deahr sees both parts of that apparent conflict with more clarity and in a more complete context. One of the secrets of Deahr's vision is that because she can see more of it, she can see right through it.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/johnny-nevin/dance-crash-deahr-art_b_2564568.html "Dance Crash, Deahr and the Art of Connection" The Huffington Post January 29, 2013] </ref>” In 2017, [[Dance Magazine]] awarded her full-length work ''The Bricklayers of Oz'' as "The Most Inventive New Work of 2017"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Best of 2017|journal=Dance Magazine|date=December 2017|page=84}}</ref> while the [[Chicago Sun-Times]] declared “There is something about Jessica Deahr’s ingenious new hip-hop dance-theater piece that is so imaginative, so playfully revisionist, and so superbly realized by all the artists involved, that it feels like an instant classic all its own.<ref>[http://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment/repaving-the-yellow-brick-road-in-ingenious-bricklayers-of-oz/ "Repaving the Yellow Brick Road in ingenious ''Bricklayers of Oz''" Chicago Sun-Times August 6, 2017]</ref>” Additionally, Deahr has been acknowledged as among the "Best in Dance" by the Chicago Tribune,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Sid|title=Sid Smith's Best in Dance 2012|work=The Chicago Tribune|date=December 13, 2012}}</ref> as a "Top Artist" by Dance Magazine<ref>{{cite news|last1=Whittenberg|first1=Zachary|title=Top Artists Confess their Guilty Pleasures|work=Dance Magazine|date=February 29, 2016}}</ref>, as a featured artist in IWU Magazine<ref>[https://www.iwu.edu/magazine/2017/spring/deahr-dance.html "Guest choreographer Jessica Deahr ’04 stretches dance students to their limits" IWU Magazine Spring, 2017]</ref> and in the [[New York Times]] best-selling book "Dancers Among Us<ref>[https://vimeo.com/29647160 "Dancers Among Us in Chicago - Sunrise at Oak St Beach" Vimeo]</ref>."
== References ==
{{reflist}}

revision.comment: clean up; HTTP→HTTPS for [[British Museum]], replaced: http://www.britishmuseum.org/ → https://www.britishmuseum.org/ (2) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[File:Brooklyn Museum 35.679 Elephant Tusk Carved with Figures in Relief.jpg|thumbnail|Kongo Elephant Tusk Carved with Figures in Relief, from the collections of the Brooklyn Museum]] '''Kongo ivories''' are some of the finest sculptural works produced by the people of the west-central Africa's Lower Congo region. In the [[Kongo Kingdom]], [[ivory]] was a precious commodity that was strictly controlled by chiefs and kings, who commissioned sculptors to produce fine ivory sculptures for their personal and courtly use. With the rise of the [[Atlantic slave trade|transatlantic trade]], ivory became one of the most valuable African [[natural resources]] sought by Western industry. Eventually, Kongo ivory carvers produced works not only for indigenous leaders and elites but also for Europeans and other foreigners.<ref name="Met Museum">{{cite web|last=Bridges|first=Nichole N.|title=Kongo Ivories|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/kong/hd_kong.htm|work=Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref>
==Afro-Portuguese ivories== Most of the earliest extant ivory carvings from sub-Saharan Africa were not made for African consumers.<ref name="Ross 1992">{{cite book|last=Ross|first=Doran|title=Elephant : the animal and its ivory in African culture|year=1992|publisher=Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California|location=Los Angeles|isbn=0930741250|authorlink=Imagining Elephants: An Overview|editor=Doran Ross}}</ref> Richly decorated oliphants, or side-blown horns, from the sixteenth century are among the earliest known of the Kongo Kingdom's royal commissions in ivory. Although made in the form of musical instruments to be used during court ceremonies, many such sculptures were likely given as gifts and made for sale to Portuguese elites, missionaries, and traders.<ref name="Met Museum" /> In the 1950s, historian [[William Buller Fagg|William Fagg]] coined the term “Afro-Portuguese ivories” to describe Kongo oliphants and other ivory sculptures from this period.<ref name="Fagg 1958">{{cite book|last=Fagg|first=William|title=Afro-Portuguese Ivories|year=1958|publisher=Batchworth Press|location=London}}</ref><ref>Emma George Ross, [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/apiv/hd_apiv.htm "Afro-Portuguese Ivories"] ''Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History''. New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, October 2002.</ref> A significant number of Afro-Portuguese ivories are in the [[British Museum]], many of them made in [[Sierra Leone]] and Benin in the 15th and 16th centuries.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=Carved+ivory+Sierra+Leone British Museum Collection]</ref><ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/search.aspx?searchText=Carved+salt-cellar+Benin British Museum Collection]</ref>
==Carved ivories for export== About the middle of the nineteenth century, a new style of ivory carving developed in the area to meet the demand of the export trade along the [[Loango Kingdom|Loango Coast]] of west-central Africa. This style consisted of fine, detailed relief carving that depicts scenes of Kongo life.<ref name=Siegmann>{{cite book|last=Siegmann|first=William C.|title=African art a century at the Brooklyn Museum|year=2009|publisher=Brooklyn Museum|location=Brooklyn, NY|isbn=9780872731639}}</ref> Scenes commonly portrayed in relief on the ivories capture the dynamic and cosmopolitan coastal activity related to the transatlantic trade.
Most carved Loango tusks are not longer than two to three feet because they were sourced from forest elephants, which are much smaller than the African savannah elephant. Full Loango tusk sculptures that were sculpted from the enormous tusks of savannah elephants are extremely rare; one notable example is now part of the [[Brooklyn Museum]]’s collection.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/71017/rec/1 For spirits and kings: African art from the Paul and Ruth Tishman collection], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on Kongo ivories
[[Category:African art]] [[Category:Ivory works of art]]

:''See also the [[Logan Medal]] of the Geological Association of Canada. The '''Logan Medal of the Arts''' was an arts prize initiated in 1907 and associated with the [[Art Institute of Chicago]], the Frank G Logan family and the [[Society for Sanity in Art]]. From 1917 through 1940, 270 awards were given for contributions to American art. The Medal was named for arts patron Frank Granger Logan, founder of the brokerage house of Logan & Bryan, who served over 50 years on the board of the Chicago Art Institute. He and his wife, Josephine Hancock Logan, administered the award consistent with their patronage of the [[Society for Sanity in Art]], which they founded in 1936, and the theme of her 1937 book ''Sanity in Art''. The Logans strongly opposed all forms of modern art, including [[cubism]], [[surrealism]], and [[abstract expressionism]]. It was not unknown for the Society of Sanity in Art to award a prize (e.g. in 1938 to [[Rudolph F. Ingerle]]) in competition with the official award by the exhibition prize committee of a prize the Logans had already sponsored. The Logans sponsored several prizes in their name. The Mr and Mrs Frank G Logan prize was awarded to a jury-selected exhibit at the American Paintings and Sculpture Exhibitions held in Chicago, and a similarly named prize was awarded to a local artist at the annual Chicago and Vicinity Exhibition for a selected exhibit. Frank G Logan prizes were also awarded at exhibitions of prints by the [[Chicago Society of Etchers]], the annual International Watercolor Exhibition and the annual International Lithography and Wood Engraving Exhibition, all held at the Chicago Art Institute. Logan prizes were also awarded by the Society for Sanity in Art at exhibitions in California. {{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=January 2011}} {{original research|date=January 2011}} {{advert|date=January 2011}} }}
[[Image:Marblehead Little Theatre, Marblehead MA.jpg|thumb|right|250px|<center>Marblehead Little Theatre</center>]] The '''Marblehead Little Theatre''' is a [[community theatre]] in [[Marblehead, Massachusetts|Marblehead]], [[Massachusetts]], founded in 1956.
It is one of the oldest continually operating community theatres in the United States.{{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}
{{coord|42|30|5.6|N|70|51|22.9|W|region:US|display=title}}
==History==
===The beginning===
One success in 1955, by members of the drama committee of the Marblehead Woman's Club, ignited the desire to tackle bigger and better things. Encouraged by the response to a one-act play, ''The Charm Racquet'', the women decided to next produce a three-act play and then went one step bolder by deciding to form a community theatre group.
Marblehead Little Theatre's first full-scale production was Moss Hart's ''Light up the Sky''. While casting the show, it became evident that a much larger group was needed, and so, husbands, sons, daughters, and friends were enlisted. The show opened on January 18, 1956, at the Marblehead Junior High School Auditorium.
And so Marblehead Little Theatre (MLT) was born and now over five decades later has proven to be one of the oldest community theatre groups in New England as well as one of the few to have continually produced shows each year.
Throughout the 1950s, MLT held its main productions at the high school using the proscenium stage. As the group gained recognition, they were asked to perform at churches, charity functions, and veteran's hospitals and began including a number of one-act plays suitable for these occasions. MLT has also performed ''Leonardo da Vinci'' as a children's presentation at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.
===The 1960s===
By the 1960s, MLT was not only doing workshops such as ''J.B.'' and ''The Lady's Not For Burning'', but they also ventured into the new theatre of the absurd with. ''Zoo Story'' and ''The Bald Soprano''. In 1963, MLT was invited to participate in the Marblehead Arts Festival, performing two one-act plays on an outdoor stage.
A big leap was made in the mid-1960s by the decision to take the plunge and do a musical. They got their feet wet by presenting ''The Fantasticks'' with a cast of seven, minimal scenery and an orchestra consisting of a pianist, a harpist, and a percussionist. The show received such an enthusiastic reception that they were inspired to stage a full-scale musical, ''Pajama Game'', in November 1965. The cast of forty came from all over the North Shore, with membership drawn from Salem, Swampscott, Peabody, Danvers, Beverly and Hamilton. This was a big production with 18 musical numbers, singing and dancing, many set changes and, most of all, a full orchestra which was presented at Salem State College's large auditorium and was a sell-out.
Since then, MLT has presented at least one musical production each year, which has become the hallmark of the group. The 1960s also saw MLT's entrance into the New England Theatre Conference Annual Community Theatre Drama Festival competition. During the 1960s MLT began awarding an annual scholarship to a member of the Marblehead High School graduating class who has participated in theatrical productions during high school as well as contributed in some way to Marblehead Little Theatre.
===The 1970s===
In 1970, MLT revived ''The Fantasticks'' and became a traveling group taking the show to Beverly for a benefit performance for the North Shore Community College. They also toured Endicott College, Arlington, Concord, and the Essex Agricultural and Technical Institute in Danvers.
Historic Abbot Hall became the setting for many musicals produced in the 1970s with the initial staging of ''Kiss Me Kate'' followed with superb performances of ''Man of La Mancha'', ''Fiddler on the Roof'', ''Brigadoon'', ''Camelot'', as well as productions for children of ''The Red Shoes'' and ''Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp''.
Perhaps the most memorable performance of the 1970s at Abbot Hall was opening night of the Bicentennial show of ''1776''. There were parties before and after the performance hosted by the Marblehead Bicentennial Commission in the Selectman's Meeting Room with the original Willard painting of the ''Spirit of '76'' as a most appropriate and inspiring backdrop.
===The 1980s===
In the 1980s, MLT began staging their productions at the new Nelson Aldrich Performing Arts Center at the Marblehead High School with a seating capacity of 766 and a stage to rival the best of Boston's professional theater. The professionalism and quality of the two major musicals staged yearly greatly enhanced the growing reputation of MLT as a high caliber community theatre. Audiences flocked to see such productions as ''The Music Man'', ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'', and ''Company''.
===The 1990s===
During the 1990s, MLT's major project has been obtaining a home of their own to stage small productions, conduct workshops, and provide space to store and build sets, to rehearse, as well as store props and costumes.
The desire to do smaller plays in addition to our{{who|date=May 2012}} yearly big musicals resulted in the production of an original play ''One Civilized Person'' in 1995 as a part of the Marblehead Festival of Arts and later, productions of ''Exit the Body'', ''The Cemetery Club'' and ''Bullshot Crummond'', all staged at the Tower School in Marblehead.
1998's major production of ''The Wizard of Oz'' staged at the Aldrich Center played to sold out audiences.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
During the production of ''The King and I'' in the Fall of 1999, the Marblehead Board of Selectmen awarded the School Street Firehouse to Marblehead Little Theatre.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
{{MarbleheadMA}}
